p.s: Description of Streptomyces castelarensis (Cercós 1954) Kumar and Goodfellow sp. nov., comb. nov.
Streptomyces castelarensis (cas.tel.ar.en′sis. N.L. masc. adj. castelarensis from Castelar, Argentina, the source of the organism).
Basonym: Streptomyces rutgersensis subsp. castelarensis Cercós 1954.
The description is based on data taken from this and previous studies (Cercós, 1954; Kämpfer et al., 1991).
Rugose ornamented spores (0.8×1.6 μm) are borne on spiral spore chains with two to six turns on inorganic salts-starch agar.
Grows well on modified Bennett's, glycerol-asparagine, oatmeal and yeast extract-malt extract agars.
On oatmeal agar the aerial spore mass colour is grey, becoming black and moist when mature, and the substrate mycelium greyish-yellow; diffusible pigments are not formed.

Melanin pigments are not produced on either peptone-yeast extract-iron or tyrosine agars. N-Acetyl-d-galactosamine, N-acetyl-d-glucosamine, cellobiose, d-fructose, d-galactose, d-glucose, d-glycerol, glycogen, maltose, d-mannitol, d-mannose, melibiose, raffinose, l-rhamnose, d-ribose, trehalose, d-xylitol and d-xylose are used as sole carbon sources, but not sucrose, l-sorbose or d-tagalose.
Additional phenotypic properties are shown in Table 1.
The type strain, ATCC 15191T (=DSM 40830T), was isolated from dust in Castelar, Argentina.
